required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Neoadjuvant Bevacizumab, Capecitabine and Radiation Therapy With or Without Oxaliplatin Locally Advanced Rectal Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Phase II Study of Bevacizumab, Capecitabine and Radiation Therapy With or Without Oxaliplatin in the Preoperative Treatment of Locally Advanced Rectal Cancer

brief_summary.textblock:
Phase II clinical trial, open-label, randomized, two arms, multicentre (possibly multinational). Academic, investigator initiated.
To assess the activity of bevacizumab (AvastinTM) in combination with capecitabine (XelodaTM) and radiation therapy with or without oxaliplatin (EloxatinTM) in the pre-operative treatment of locally advanced rectal cancer, followed by TME (total mesorectal excision).

primary_outcome.measure: Pathologic Response at Surgery. Overview of Complete Pathologic Responses, Good and Little Tumour Regression Rates at Surgery.
primary_outcome.description: Dworak tumour regression grades (TRG) were used to assess pathologic response: TRG0=no regression. TRG1=dominant tumor mass with obvious fibrosis and/or vasculopathy; TRG2=dominant fibrotic changes with few tumour cells or groups; TRG3=very few (difficult to find microscopically) tumour cells in fibrotic tissue with or without mucus substance. TRG4=no intact viable tumour cells, only fibrotic mass or presence of mucin lakes without associated malignant cells (total tumour regression). Pathologic assessments of tumour response post chemoradiotherapy as provided by investigators (read by local pathologists on operative specimens) were reviewed centrally for all pts for whom surgical materials were available (centrally reviewed set). The diagnosis of independent central reviewers primed. Pathologic complete response rates (TRG4) are reported (%). Good (TRG3 and TRG4 together) and little (TRG 0,1 and 2) tumour regression rates are summarized. For these 2 last rows, % add to 100.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Histopathologic R0 and Negative CRM Resection
secondary_outcome.description: Histopathologic R0 resection rate was defined as margins histologically negative for tumour involvement after resection. The circumferential resection margin (CRM) is considered to be involved if microscopic tumour is present <1mm from or at the inked circumferential or radial resection margin. Data on quality of mesorectal excision were expected but not collected consistently.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Pathologic Complete Response at Surgery. Number of Participants With Good or Little Pathological Tumour Regression at Surgery.
secondary_outcome.description: Dworak tumour regression grades (TRG) were used to assess pathologic response: TRG0=no regression. TRG1=dominant tumor mass with obvious fibrosis and/or vasculopathy; TRG2=dominant fibrotic changes with few tumour cells or groups; TRG3=very few (difficult to find microscopically) tumour cells in fibrotic tissue with or without mucus substance. TRG4=no intact viable tumour cells, only fibrotic mass or presence of mucin lakes without associated malignant cells (total tumour regression). Pathologic assessments of tumour response post chemoradiotherapy as provided by investigators (read by local pathologists on operative specimens) were reviewed centrally for all pts for whom surgical materials were available (centrally reviewed set). The diagnosis of independent central reviewers primed. Pathologic complete response rates (TRG4) are reported (%). Good (TRG3 and TRG4 together) and little (TRG 0,1 and 2) tumour regression rates are summarized. For these 2 last rows, % add to 100.

Baseline tumour measurements were performed within 4 weeks prior to treatment start (RECIST). The same methods of assessment (CT and/or MRI) were used for each measurable lesion at baseline and during follow-up. Complete Response (CR) is disappearance of all clinical and radiological evidence of tumour (both target and non-target lesions). Partial Response (PR) is at least a 30% decrease in the sum of LD of target lesions, taking as reference the baseline sum of tumour longest diameters (LD). Stable Disease (SD) is steady state of disease. Neither sufficient shrinkage to qualify for PR nor sufficient increase to qualify for PD. Progressive Disease (PD) is at least a 20% increase in the sum of LD of measured lesions taking as references the smallest sum LD recorded since the treatment started. Appearance of new lesions constitutes PD. In exceptional circumstances, unequivocal progression of non-target lesions was considered evidence of PD.

secondary_outcome.measure: Types and Numbers of Adverse Events - General Overview
secondary_outcome.description: Adverse events graded as per NCI CTCAE (US National Cancer Institute Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events) version 3.0. All Serious Adverse Events occurrences are reported and counts are summarized here; all Adverse Events (all grades) related and not related to study treatment are reported and summarized here; all severe laboratory events (hematology and biochemistry Gr 3 and higher) are reported and summarized here; all severe postoperative complications (Gr 3 and higher) occurred within the first month post surgery are reported and summarized here. See section Adverse events for details.

secondary_outcome.measure: Recurrence Rates and Disease Free Survival
secondary_outcome.description: Counts and proportions of patients experiencing recurrence of disease (local and distant).
Counts and proportions of patients deceased (post-study).

arm_group.description: Oxaliplatin, Bevacizumab and Capecitabine concurrently with radiotherapy.
Bevacizumab and Capecitabine concurrently with radiotherapy

intervention.description: 825 mg/m2 ; 25 days - 5days per week, concurrent with radiotherapy

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adenocarcinoma of rectum measurable (RECIST), locally advanced (defined by MRI - Tumour beyond mesorectal fascia (T4) or Tumour ≤ 2 mm from mesorectal fascia or T3 tumour < 5 cm from anal verge
- Patient is at least 18 years of age
- Good organ function
Exclusion Criteria:
- Evidence of distant metastases
- Contraindication for bevacizumab
- Pregnant or breastfeeding women.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Eighty-four patients were included. First patient enrolled: 22-Jun-2009. Last patient enrolled: 29-Sep-2013. Participating sites: UZ Leuven, Erasme Hospital Bruxelles, Cliniques Universitaires St-Luc Bruxelles, AZ St. Lucas Brugge, AZ Groeninge Kortrijk, CHU Sart-Tilman Liege, OLVZ Aalst, H. Hart Ziekenhuis Roeselare, Cl. Saint Elisabeth Namur
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Target population was represented by patients with locally advanced rectal cancer (tumour beyond mesorectal fascia (T4) or tumour ≤ 2 mm from mesorectal fascia or T3 tumour < 5 cm from anal verge by MRI), histologically confirmed. Pts were screened as per incl and excl criteria per protocol. Screening failures were not recorded in the eCRF.

group.title: AXE (ARM 1)
group.description: Oxaliplatin, Bevacizumab and Capecitabine concurrently with radiotherapy. Oxaliplatin: Administered on days 15,22,29,36 en 43; 50 mg/m2 Bevacizumab: Administered on days 1,15,29 and 43 ; 5mg/kg Capecitabine: 825 mg/m2 ; 25 days - 5days per week, concurrent with radiotherapy Radiotherapy: Total dose 45Gy

group.title: AX (ARM 2)
group.description: Bevacizumab and Capecitabine concurrently with radiotherapy Bevacizumab: Administered on days 1,15,29 and 43 ; 5mg/kg Capecitabine: 825 mg/m2 ; 25 days - 5days per week, concurrent with radiotherapy Radiotherapy: Total dose 45Gy

participants_list.participants: Patient in Arm 1 with clinical complete response and no surgery is in follow up (joined this period)
Patients with no central review material and with adverse event are in followup (joined this period)

group.title: AXE (ARM 1)
group.description: Oxaliplatin, Bevacizumab and Capecitabine concurrently with radiotherapy. group.description: Bevacizumab and Capecitabine concurrently with radiotherapy Bevacizumab: Administered on days 1,15,29 and 43 ; 5mg/kg Capecitabine: 825 mg/m2 ; 25 days - 5days per week, concurrent with radiotherapy Radiotherapy: Total dose 45Gy

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

measure.title: ECOG PS (Performance Status)
measure.description: ECOG PS = 0 Fully active, able to carry on all pre-disease performance without restriction; ECOG PS = 1 Restricted in physically strenuous activity but ambulatory and able to carry out work of a light or sedentary nature, e.g., light house work, office work

measure.title: Distance from tumour to anal verge
measure.description: Distance from tumour to anal verge measured during colonoscopy (in cm).

measure.title: Distance to CRM
measure.description: Distance to CRM measured by MRI

measure.title: Tumour stage
measure.description: Tumour staging was done using clinical, radiological and pathological assessments on rectal biopsies. Tumors (T) were graded using the colon and rectum cancer staging (TNM, American Joint Committee on Cancer 7th edition) where T2 tumors are less severe then T3 tumors and T4 tumors respectively.

measure.title: Nodal stage
measure.description: Nodal staging was done using clinical, radiological and pathological assessments where applicable. Lymph node involvement (N) was graded using the colon and rectum cancer staging (TNM, American Joint Committee on Cancer 7th edition) where N0 is no regional lymph node involved and N1 is less severe then N2 involvement.

class.title: N2 (metastasis in 4 or more regional lymph nodes)

outcome.title: Pathologic Response at Surgery. Overview of Complete Pathologic Responses, Good and Little Tumour Regression Rates at Surgery.
outcome.description: Dworak tumour regression grades (TRG) were used to assess pathologic response: TRG0=no regression. TRG1=dominant tumor mass with obvious fibrosis and/or vasculopathy; TRG2=dominant fibrotic changes with few tumour cells or groups; TRG3=very few (difficult to find microscopically) tumour cells in fibrotic tissue with or without mucus substance. TRG4=no intact viable tumour cells, only fibrotic mass or presence of mucin lakes without associated malignant cells (total tumour regression). Pathologic assessments of tumour response post chemoradiotherapy as provided by investigators (read by local pathologists on operative specimens) were reviewed centrally for all pts for whom surgical materials were available (centrally reviewed set). The diagnosis of independent central reviewers primed. Pathologic complete response rates (TRG4) are reported (%). Good (TRG3 and TRG4 together) and little (TRG 0,1 and 2) tumour regression rates are summarized. For these 2 last rows, % add to 100.
outcome.population: Patients who had undertaken surgery and had pathology materials available for central review (centrally reviewed subset)

outcome.title: Clinical Response Rate
outcome.description: Baseline tumour measurements were performed within 4 weeks prior to treatment start (RECIST). The same methods of assessment (CT and/or MRI) were used for each measurable lesion at baseline and during follow-up. Complete Response (CR) is disappearance of all clinical and radiological evidence of tumour (both target and non-target lesions). Partial Response (PR) is at least a 30% decrease in the sum of LD of target lesions, taking as reference the baseline sum of tumour longest diameters (LD). Stable Disease (SD) is steady state of disease. Neither sufficient shrinkage to qualify for PR nor sufficient increase to qualify for PD. Progressive Disease (PD) is at least a 20% increase in the sum of LD of measured lesions taking as references the smallest sum LD recorded since the treatment started. Appearance of new lesions constitutes PD. In exceptional circumstances, unequivocal progression of non-target lesions was considered evidence of PD.
outcome.population: Intent to treat, all registered patients

group.description: Oxaliplatin, Bevacizumab and Capecitabine concurrently with radiotherapy. outcome.title: Types and Numbers of Adverse Events - General Overview
outcome.description: Adverse events graded as per NCI CTCAE (US National Cancer Institute Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events) version 3.0. All Serious Adverse Events occurrences are reported and counts are summarized here; all Adverse Events (all grades) related and not related to study treatment are reported and summarized here; all severe laboratory events (hematology and biochemistry Gr 3 and higher) are reported and summarized here; all severe postoperative complications (Gr 3 and higher) occurred within the first month post surgery are reported and summarized here. See section Adverse events for details.

reported_events.time_frame: From signature of ICF to 30 days post surgery with follow-up for residual toxicity after this period if applicable
reported_events.desc: All SAE occurences are reported and displayed below. Only Gr 3-4-5 adverse events (serious and non serious) are reported in this report.

group.title: AXE (ARM 1)
group.description: Oxaliplatin, Bevacizumab and Capecitabine concurrently with radiotherapy. Oxaliplatin: Administered on days 15,22,29,36 en 43; 50 mg/m2 Bevacizumab: Administered on days 1,15,29 and 43 ; 5mg/kg Capecitabine: 825 mg/m2 ; 25 days - 5days per week, concurrent with radiotherapy Radiotherapy: Total dose 45Gy

group.title: AX (ARM 2)
group.description: Bevacizumab and Capecitabine concurrently with radiotherapy Bevacizumab: Administered on days 1,15,29 and 43 ; 5mg/kg Capecitabine: 825 mg/m2 ; 25 days - 5days per week, concurrent with radiotherapy Radiotherapy: Total dose 45Gy

event.description: Rectal haemorrhage Gr 2 following rectal biopsy. During chemoradiotherapy
Diarrhea Gr 3 - During chemoradiotherapy
Fistula Gr 3 - Postoperative
Anastomotic leak Gr 3; 2 in arm 1 and 3 in arm 2 - all events also SAE - Postoperative
Obstruction GI Gr 2 and Gr 3; both arm 1 Postoperative
Presacral hematoma Gr 2 - Postoperative
Fever Gr 1 - During chemoradiotherapy
Febrile neutropenia Gr 3 - During chemoradiotherapy
Catheter related infection Gr 4 - During chemoradiotherapy
Urinary tract infection Gr 2 (1 in each arm) and 1 Urinary tract infection Gr 3 in arm 1 - During chemoradiotherapy
Catheter site infection Gr 3 with positive hemocultures - Postoperative
5 peri-anal wound infections Gr 3 (4 in arm 1; 1 in arm 2) ; 1 wound with evisceration Gr 4 in arm 1 ; 1 Gr 5 wound infection in a patient with tumor break during surgery in arm 2
Neuropathy, motor (cranial, palate, pharynx) Gr 3 (swallowing problems) - During chemoradiotherapy
Seizure Gr 2 in a patient with epileptic background - During chemoradiotherapy
Depression Gr 3 - During chemoradiotherapy
Lung embolism Gr 5 - Postoperative
Platelet count decreased Gr 3 - during chemoradiotherapy
Hemorrhage with surgery Gr 3
Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation Gr 3 - during chemoradiotherapy
Hematoma Gr 3 in 1 pt in arm 2 (also SAE) - postoperative
Hematoma Gr 3 (also an SAE) - FU post EOT visit
Hypertension Gr 3 - baseline
Hypertension Gr 3 in 2 pts in arm 2 - during chemoradiotherapy
Cardiopulmonary arrest Gr 5 - FU post EOT visit
Pt with baseline Meniere's disease Gr 3 (since 1999) - Baseline
Anorexia Gr 3 - during chemoradiotherapy
Diarrhea Gr 3 in 4 pts in arm 1 (three episodes were an SAE) - during chemoradiotherapy
Pain gastro-intestinal - anal pain Gr 3
Leak GI Gr 3 - postoperative
Obstruction GI Gr 3 in 2 pts in arm 1 (for 1 also an SAE) and in 1 pt in arm 2 (also an SAE) - postoperative
Stomach pain Gr 3 and pain due to leak Gr 3 - postoperative
Purulent discharge from the anus Gr - - postoperative
Ascites Gr 5 - FU post EOT visit
Dysphagia Gr 3 - FU post EOT visit
Fatigue Gr 3 (2 pts in arm 1 and 1 pt in arm 2 - also an SAE for this pt) - during chemoradiotherapy
Sweating Gr 3 - Postoperative
Febrile neutropenia Gr 3 (also an SAE) - during chemoradiotherapy
Catheter site infection Gr 3 (also an SAE) - during chemoradiotherapy
Sepsis Gr 3 and septic shock Gr 4 - during chemoradiotherapy
5 peri-anal wound infections Gr 3 ; 1 wound infection with evisceration Gr 4 ; 1 Gr 5 wound infection in a patient with tumor break during surgery
Peritonitis Gr 5 (tumor break during surgery) - part of SAE

event.sub_title: Infection due to leak of anastomosis
event.description: Infection due to leak of anastomosis Gr 3 (part of an SAE) - follow-up
Hypocalcemia Gr 3 - during chemoradiotherapy
Hyponatremia Gr 3 - during chemoradiotherapy
Pain musculoskeletal Gr 3 - Postoperative
Pain muskuloskeletal Gr 3 - postoperative
Hypokalemia Gr 3 - during chemoradiotherapy
Neuropathy sensory Gr 3 - during chemoradiotherapy
Syncope Gr 3 - during chemoradiotherapy
Neuropathy -cranial Gr 3 (also an SAE) - FU post EOT visit
Depression Gr 3 - also an SAE - during chemoradiotherapy
Leak GU Gr 5 - postoperative
Sore throat Gr 3 and laryngeal pain Gr 3 in one patient in arm 2 - during chemoradiotherapy
Dermatitis associated with radiotherapy Gr 3
Rash Gr 3 - during chemoradiotherapy
DVT Gr 3 - Postoperative
Embolism Gr 4 and embolism Gr 5 - both in arm 2

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The Sponsor is an academic institution and not the drug market authorization holder. Participating PIs were selected from other academic institutions. Participating PIs cannot publish full or partial study results before final publication by Sponsor, but they will be nominated as co-authors based on patient accrual at each participating site. Own results can be published afterwards by participant PIs, with the agreement of the Sponsor.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: The study was not powered to allow for formal statistical comparisons between arms
